metadata.case_name: C. Gupta & Ors. v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: Detention orders under the Preventive Detention Act, 1950, served on the appellants on 26th February 1950.

Grounds for detention served on appellants on 14th March 1950. Specimen: Assisting operations of Communist Party of India (CPI) declared unlawful under s.16 Indian Criminal Law Amendment Act 1908; member of CPI Kishan front fomenting trouble amongst peasants in Howrah District; worker of CPI fomenting trouble amongst tramways men and workers in Calcutta, inciting violence in speeches at University Hall.
Under Bengal Criminal Law Amendment Act 1930, large number of persons detained; validity challenged in High Court, judgment expected end February 1950.
Preventive Detention Act 1950 passed by Parliament last week of February 1950.

Supplementary grounds served on 16th July 1950 in continuation of grounds of 14th March 1950. Specimen: As Secretary Bengal Chatkar Mazdoor Union, member Executive Committee Federation of Mercantile Employees Union, honorary reporter Khabar newspaper (CPI organ), carried disruptive programme of CPI; on 29th July 1948 led procession at Howrah preaching discontent against Government.

Second set of grounds communicated on 22nd or 23rd July 1950 in continuation of 16th July order. Specimen: In meeting 19th March 1947 under Calcutta Tramway Workers Union, threatened disaster if tram cars taken out 20th March 1947, said would remove tram lines and cut wires; on 13th June 1948 presided over meeting Students Federation (CPI controlled) advocating withdrawal of ban on CPI and Swadhinta.
Appellants applied for Rule of habeas corpus separately under s.491 CrPC; High Court issued Rule on 21st July 1950 to Chief Secretary Government of West Bengal.
High Court rejected habeas corpus petitions.

legal_issues.text: Whether communication of grounds on 14th March 1950 complied with 'as soon as may be' under Article 22(5) of Constitution.
Whether there was non-compliance with procedure under Article 22(5) and s.7 Preventive Detention Act in supplying grounds, depriving earliest opportunity to make representation.
Whether supplementary grounds of 16th July 1950 were new or additional grounds, violating Article 22(5).
Whether grounds were vague, not constituting valid grounds and preventing representation.
Whether large number of detention orders overnight indicated bad faith.

petitioner_arguments.text: Communication of grounds on 14th March 1950 not 'as soon as may be' under Article 22(5).
Non-compliance with Article 22(5) and s.7 Preventive Detention Act in manner of supplying grounds, no earliest opportunity for representation.

Supplementary grounds of 16th July were additional/new grounds not before authorities on 26th Feb, obligation absolute to communicate as soon as may be; shows original grounds insufficient, afterthought.
Grounds vague, not sufficient for satisfaction under s.3 or for representation.
Large number of fresh orders overnight shows bad faith, no individual application of mind.

respondent_arguments.text: Delay in grounds justified by sudden large number of cases post Preventive Detention Act.
Supplementary grounds not new but details of original grounds of 14th March.
Grounds not vague; complied with procedural requirements for representation.

court_reasoning.text: Agree with High Court: 16-day delay justified given large number of detentions under prior Act, sudden need to serve under new Act on 26th Feb.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provincial Government had to deal with large number suddenly.

court_reasoning.text: Apply principles from Case No.22/1950 on Art22(5) rights.
Supplementary grounds not new/additional but details of second heads in original 14th March grounds; read whole communication, not just opening words.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Contents show elaboration, not fresh grounds.

court_reasoning.text: Vague grounds differ from irrelevant; court examines sufficiency for representation, not for authority's subjective satisfaction under s.3.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Two distinct tests; High Court found not vague.

court_reasoning.text: No bad faith; authorities already applied minds under local Acts, fresh orders under new Act straightforward.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Minds already made up on necessity.

holdings.text: Communication of grounds on 14th March complied with Art22(5) 'as soon as may be'.
No violation of Art22(5) or s.7 in supplying grounds or opportunity for representation.
Supplementary grounds not new; valid elaborations.
Grounds not vague; sufficient for representation and authority satisfaction (subjective).
No bad faith in bulk orders.

precedents_cited.case_name: Case No. 22 of 1950 (The State of Bombay v. Atma Ram Sridhar Vaidya)
precedents_cited.relevance: Detailed principles on Art22(5) rights, nature of grounds, vagueness.
Explanation of new vs elaborative grounds.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for appeal; procedural safeguards for preventive detention.

statutes_cited.name: Preventive Detention Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Authority for detention orders; communication of grounds.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1930
statutes_cited.relevance: Prior detention regime whose validity challenged.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal against High Court rejection of habeas corpus petitions, upholding validity of detention orders and compliance with Art22(5) in communication of grounds and representations.

key_quotes.text: 'A description of the contents of the second communication as supplementary grounds does not necessarily make them additional or new grounds. One has to look at the contents...'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies test for supplementary vs new grounds.

key_quotes.text: 'The sufficiency of the grounds, which gives rise to the satisfaction of the Provincial Government, is not a matter for examination by the court.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes judicial review limits on subjective satisfaction.

key_quotes.text: 'Vague grounds stand on the same footing as irrelevant grounds.' (rejected by court)
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner
